description.narrative: AfroBarometern (AB) är en serie av undersökningar av allmänhetens inställningar till demokrati, marknader och civilsamhället i Afrika. AB skall impl. i ett 30-35 Afr. länder. Exempel på mål med programmet är att öka ABs synbarhet bland politiska aktörer och att fortsätta bygga institutionell kapacitet för vetenskaplig forskning.

The Afrobarometer (AB) is a series of gallups assessing popular perceptions concerning democracy, markets, and civil society in Africa. AB intends to implement its program in 30-35 African countries. Exampel of objective with the programme is to increase AB visibility amongst political actors and to continue building inst. capacity of scientific reasearch.

The overarching objective of Afrobarometer (AB) is African citizens' opinions about democracy and development are heard and made part of the public policy debate while the following overall objectives were set out in the recently finalized phase of the program; • To expand coverage to 35 countries • To enhance the visibility of the Afrobarometer among African Policy Actors through professionalization of the Afrobarometer’s Communications Program, prioritizing the timeliness, accessibility and continuity in the release of results, and building ongoing engagement with stakeholders. • To continue building Institutional Capacity for survey research and scientific analysis in Africa. • To continue strengthening and indigenizing Network Management.

description.narrative: Afrobarometer achieved commendable results by conducting surveys in 37 countries and exceeding its initial target of 35 countries in Round 5 and 6. This wide coverage is recorded as the highest since its establishment. According to an external evaluation of the programme commissioned by Sida, not only did AB exceeded contractual obligations in the speed of delivery of the results and but also in the manner of their dissemination. The fact that these targets were achieved at the face of significant financial crisis due to shifting of priorities in the global funding landscape away from democracy and governance other contextual and political challenges makes AB’s success notable. AB has showed improvement from previous years in enhancing its visibility and engagement of stakeholders. Yet, there is a long way to go in creating and strengthening systematic partnership with research institutions, think tanks, journalists and other national partners. In terms of capacity development, significant impacts have been achieved, notably in providing indepth, hands-on training to national partners prior to roll-out of survey rounds and building communications and data management capacity. In particular, the Summer Schools were widely viewed as pivotal in ensuring that partners understood the underlying reasoning behind why and how the survey was designed and how it fed into social research intended on impacting on the policy discourse. AB has also gained results in incorporating the that the gender dimension in the conduct of surveys as well as the production of publications. 50% female representativity in the survey samples was sustained throughout the survey rounds. The number of female fieldworkers equally reached an average ratio of 44% in Round 5 and 47% in Round 6, against a target of 40%. Afrobarometer’s Monitoring & Evaluation system also recorded a jump in the number of female authors of Afrobarometer publications. However, gender indicators are judged by the Evaluation Team to be insufficiently mainstreamed into the reporting system to provide a clear picture on the number of women reached through Afrobarometer activities (i.e. among users).
